; ;

;

;库姆斯的一位代表，他的名字是 Puff Daddy、P Diddy、Diddy 和 Love，库姆斯否认了这些说法，写道该诉讼“充满了毫无根据和令人发指的谎言”，并且是在文图拉向这位大亨索要 3000 万美元之后发生的。

;

;库姆斯经营着一个商业帝国，业务涵盖从酒精到音乐的所有领域，并且自 1993 年创立 Bad Boy 唱片公司以来，她一直是嘻哈界的重要人物。Ventura 与 Bad Boy 签约，并表示她和 Combs 在她 19 岁时开始约会，他“引诱”她进入“招摇的、快节奏的、药物驱动的生活方式”。诉讼称，他变得有控制欲和虐待倾向，经常对她拳打脚踢和跺脚。

;

;< /div>; Fri, 17 Nov 2023 06:52:01 +0800 ‘Astounding’: Alabama woman with two uteruses is pregnant in both wombshttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/nov/16/alabama-woman-two-uterus-rare-pregnancy
;;2023-11-16T22:17:02Z;
;
;;2023 年 5 月 23 日，凯尔西·海切尔 (Kelsey Hatcher) 和她的丈夫凯莱布·海切尔 (Caleb Hatcher)，当时他们发现她怀着两个孩子两个子宫。
;

;阿拉巴马州一名拥有两个子宫的妇女正在两个子宫中怀上女婴，据医生称，这是一次“令人震惊”且罕见的怀孕。

;

;凯尔西·哈切尔 (Kelsey Hatcher)，32 岁- 三个孩子的老妈妈出生时患有一种罕见的子宫异常，称为双子宫或两个子宫。然而，直到去年春天，她才被诊断出患有这种疾病，当时她发现自己的两个子宫都怀孕了。

;
;

;;相关：;;姐姐首次在英国捐赠子宫后，妇女“欣喜若狂”;;

;

;海切尔说她的丈夫几乎不相信她。

;

;“他说：‘你在撒谎，’我说：‘不，我没有，’”海切尔告诉;NBC新闻;。< /p>;

;双子宫影响约 0.3% 的女性。根据;生育研究人员;。

;

;“两个卵巢同时或大约在同一时间排卵的事实非常令人震惊，”斯坦福大学医学院研究员海莉·米勒博士说妇产科接受过母胎医学方面的培训，并且是美国妇产科医师学会的成员。

;

;当哈彻正在为两个婴儿做准备时，医生们正准备为哈彻的分娩提供额外的工作人员。拥有两个子宫和两个子宫颈的女性可能会给医生带来特殊的挑战。

;

;“我照顾过许多拥有两个子宫和两个子宫颈的患者，即使是拥有两个子宫颈和两个子宫的引产也常常具有挑战性。 ”，米勒说。

;

;婴儿甚至可能出生相隔数小时或数天，因为子宫可以独立进入宫缩。哈彻的医生还向 NBC 强调了对于有两个子宫的女性进行剖腹产的风险，即可能会出现更多失血，因为需要两个切口（每个子宫各一个）。

;

;同意怀孕是一件了不起的事，但有争议的一个问题是如何描述孩子们——兄弟姐妹还是异卵双胞胎？据;当地新闻电台 WVTM 报道，Hatcher 的预产期是圣诞节。 ;.

; Fri, 17 Nov 2023 06:22:01 +0800 TikTok ‘aggressively’ taking down videos promoting Bin Laden letterhttps://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/nov/16/tiktok-bin-laden-letter-to-america-videos-removal
;;2023-11-16T20:57:14Z;
;
;;手机上的 tiktok 图标
;

;TikTok 正在“主动且积极地”撤下视频，从而推动了;奥萨马·本·拉登写的信;阐述了他对 2001 年 9 月 11 日恐怖袭击的合理性该公司在周四的一份声明中表示。

;

;参考 2002 年这封信的视频于 20 年前在《卫报》网站上发布，本周早些时候已在多个社交网络上传播，但传播范围尚不清楚

;

;TikTok 在;声明中表示，“宣传这封信的内容显然违反了我们关于支持任何形式恐怖主义的规定” ;。 “我们正在积极主动地删除这些内容，并调查它是如何进入我们的平台的。”

;

;过去几天，剖析和回应本拉登“致美国的信”的视频在以色列的 TikTok 上受到关注。 -哈马斯冲突。截至周四，话题标签 #letteroamerica 的浏览量已超过 1000 万次，之后该公司屏蔽了对其的搜索。

;

;在作家 Yashar Ali 发布的一条超级剪辑中，这些剪辑被转移到了 X（以前的 Twitter）上，他写道： “数千”个视频在 TikTok 上激增。阿里的推文本身就获得了超过 11,000 次转发和 2,380 万次浏览。

;

;“TikTok 来自各个年龄段、种族、民族和背景的人。他们中的许多人表示，读了这封信让他们大开眼界，他们再也不会以同样的方式看待地缘政治问题了。”阿里写道。

;

;TikTok 在声明中表示，公开这封信的视频数量实际情况较低。 《卫报》无法独立核实这些视频的传播或观看范围。

;

;该公司表示：“TikTok 上的视频数量很少，关于我们平台上的视频趋势的报道不准确。这并不是 TikTok 所独有的，并且已经出现在多个平台和媒体上。”

;

;有关本·拉登信件的 TikTok 视频经常与《观察家报》联系在一起，该报于 2002 年 11 月 24 日发布了全文翻译。< /p>;

;为了回应这封信的重新传播，卫报新闻和媒体于 2023 年 11 月 15 日将其删除，并代之以这样的声明：“我们网站上发布的文字记录已在社交媒体上广泛传播，但没有完整的上下文。因此，我们决定将其删除，并将读者引导至最初对其进行背景介绍的新闻文章。”

; Fri, 17 Nov 2023 05:22:02 +0800 David DePape found guilty in hammer attack on Nancy Pelosi’s husbandhttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/nov/16/david-depape-guilty-paul-pelosi-trial
;;2023-11-16T19:38:13Z;
;
;;2022 年 10 月 28 日，南希·佩洛西的丈夫在这对夫妇位于旧金山的家中遭到袭击（如图）。
;< p>;在旧金山家中袭击南希·佩洛西丈夫的右翼阴谋论者戴维·德帕普 (David DePape) 已被判犯有企图绑架和袭击罪。

;

;旧金山的陪审团审议了大约八个小时，才判定德帕普有罪。企图绑架一名联邦官员并袭击一名联邦官员的直系亲属。面临最高 50 年监禁的德帕普在周四宣读判决时没有做出反应。

;

;联邦陪审团的决定是在一场戏剧性的审判之后做出的，其中 ;保罗·佩洛西就他 28 日遭受的“创伤性”锤子袭击作证; 2022 年 10 月，中期选举前几天。德帕普也出庭为自己辩护，称他计划审问这位前众议院议长，并将她的视频发布到网上。

;
;

;;相关：;;佩洛西袭击者计划穿着独角兽服装并在网上发布审讯;;

;

;袭击美国官员直系亲属、意图报复该官员履行职责的指控，最高可判处 30 年徒刑，并指控企图绑架一名美国官员最高可被判处 20 年徒刑。德帕普在州法院面临多项指控，包括谋杀未遂、使用致命武器袭击、入室盗窃和虐待老年人。在该州案件中，他可能面临无期徒刑，并已表示无罪，但审判尚未确定。

;

;检察官表示，凌晨 2 点左右袭击开始时，德帕普冲破了家中的一扇门。在佩洛西家的后面，遇到了当时 82 岁的保罗·佩洛西。他当时正在睡觉。据称德帕普说：“南希在哪里？南希在哪儿？”因为他;站在保罗佩洛西之上; 手里拿着扎带和锤子。闯入事件期间，南希·佩洛西 (Nancy Pelosi) 正在华盛顿。

;

;保罗·佩洛西 (Paul Pelosi) 设法报警，当两名警察赶到时，警察看到德帕普击中了演讲者丈夫的头部，导致他昏迷不醒。保罗·佩洛西因颅骨骨折、手和手臂受伤住院。警方的随身摄像机镜头捕捉到了部分事件，一名联邦调查局特工作证说，视频显示德帕普至少打了他三下。走进房子，看着他，看着锤子和领带，我意识到自己处于严重危险之中，所以我尽量保持冷静，”保罗·佩洛西 ;向陪审员讲述;。

;

;DePape 有记录的历史;宣扬阴谋论;和远-正确的消息。在 Facebook 上，他分享了虚假声称 2020 年选举被唐纳德·特朗普窃取的视频，以及有关 1 月 6 日叛乱的错误信息。

;

;在法庭上，德帕普在谈到自己的政治信仰并解释自己是如何来到这里时哭了。支持一些毫无根据的说法，即一群恋童癖者是美国政府的幕后黑手。他还表示，他想与南希·佩洛西谈论 2016 年大选，并打算穿着充气独角兽服装向她提问。 “他从来都不是我的目标，我很抱歉他受伤了，”德帕普 ;谈到保罗·佩洛西;。

;

;德帕普和他的律师并没有否认他实施了袭击。他的律师乔迪·林克(Jodi Linker)辩称，他针对南希·佩洛西并不是为了报复她的公务，而是因为他“全身心地”相信阴谋论。在;开场白;中，她说他正在努力阻止虐待儿童和腐败：“这不是一部侦探小说。但政府没有承认‘为什么’——而‘为什么’在本案中很重要。”

;

; Fri, 17 Nov 2023 03:22:01 +0800 Argentinian ex-officer who was charged over 23 murders dies in Berlinhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/16/argentinian-luis-kyburg-charged-over-murders-dies-in-berlin
;;2023-11-16T18:33:27Z;
;
;;向 2017 年 3 月全国真相纪念日期间阿根廷军事独裁期间失踪的约 30,000 人致敬
;

;一名阿根廷前军官在柏林自然死亡，几周后他被指控在该国军事独裁期间谋杀了 23 名左翼团体成员。

;

;柏林检察官表示，这位 75 岁的前海军军官涉嫌在 1976 年和 1977 年绑架、失踪、折磨和谋杀 23 名年轻人。

;

;他们没有透露嫌疑人的姓名，但只透露了嫌疑人的姓名。欧洲宪法与人权中心 (ECCHR) 帮助受害者亲属对嫌疑人提起诉讼，将嫌疑人命名为 Luis Kyburg。

;
;

;;相关：;;被指控在阿根廷犯有人权罪行的前军官被发现居住在柏林;

;
;

;阿根廷军事独裁统治期间估计有 30,000 人失踪，该独裁统治在 20 世纪 70 年代和 80 年代针对可疑的左翼政治批评家发起了暴力运动。

;

;Kyburg据信，该精锐海军部队的指挥官对至少 150 人的死亡负有责任，并于 2013 年在他所属的军事特遣部队的其他成员在阿根廷被定罪后逃往柏林。

;

;他拥有阿根廷和德国双重国籍，表面上平静地生活了七年，直到《图片报》披露了他在首都的存在。

;

;经过与阿根廷官员合作、采访众多目击者的长时间调查后，并搜查了他在柏林的公寓，并于本月提出了起诉书。但根据柏林检察官办公室的一份声明，随后发现该男子已于 10 月自然死亡。

;

;“被告的死亡突然结束了亲属数十年的努力。以及阿根廷和德国的调查当局，”柏林总检察长玛格丽特·科珀斯 (Margarete Koppers) 说。 “这对受害者家属来说是极其困难和痛苦的，我对他们表示最深切的同情。”

;

;ECCHR秘书长沃尔夫冈·卡莱克(Wolfgang Kaleck)表示，很遗憾受害者及其家人无法见到他们。正义得到了伸张，特别是“柏林检察官提出了全面而可靠的起诉书，基伯格的大多数同伙已被阿根廷法院定罪”。

;

;被捕后，受害者被带到海军基地检察官称，并在嫌疑人知情的情况下对他施以酷刑。一些人被带到其他地点并被释放，然后在分阶段的对抗中被枪杀。

;

;大多数人在“死亡飞行”中被杀 - ;他们被从飞机上扔下身亡;。

; Fri, 17 Nov 2023 02:52:02 +0800 Elon Musk agrees with tweet accusing Jews of ‘hatred against whites’https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/nov/16/elon-musk-antisemitic-tweet-adl

;律师表示，英国部长们的最新计划是为了获得高调卢旺达的现行政策不太可能克服;周三在最高法院击败了他们;。

;

;五名法官一致驳回政府驱逐在英国寻求庇护者的计划后前往东非国家，;Rishi Sunak 表示; 他将通过立法确保卢旺达是安全的，以确保航班能够继续进行。

; <英国首相还表示，他将与卢旺达签订一项新条约，保证从英国驱逐到卢旺达的人不会被遣返回自己的国家，这一过程被称为驱回，其风险是最高层的核心。法院驳回了政府的上诉。

;但律师表示，此类改变不会实现苏纳克结束他所谓的法律“旋转木马”的目标，并且很可能仍会与法院发生冲突。

;

;Adam Wagner, a human rights barrister at Doughty Street chambers, said the supreme court justices “started by saying ​non-refoulement is a really fundamental concept, and it's contained in lots of different sources of law. So the government can legislate to say two plus two is five but it doesn't make two plus two [equal] five. They can legislate to say actually Rwanda is safe; it doesn't make Rwanda safe as a matter of international and domestic law.”

;

;He cited the supreme court's reference to a similar treaty between Rwanda and Israel, in which it said there had been “a failure to abide by assurances (including an assurance of non-refoulement)”.

;

;Wagner said: “You can't change cultures by agreements and, secondly, the court said it didn't trust Rwanda to honour the agreement. So those are the facts. They've got to change and I can't see how they can change those facts without actually changing the reality on the ground. Legislation won't change those facts and neither will a treaty.”

;

;Many rightwing Conservatives' ire has been aimed at the European convention on human rights, but lawyers stressed that it was just one of many treaties binding the UK to the principle of non-refoulement.

;

;Schona Jolly KC, a human rights barrister at Cloisters chambers, said: “The government is not engaging with that detail in its own magical thinking. The facts on the ground matter, and those facts formed the basis of our own ;supreme court's judgment;. Legislating by decree won't magically change those facts, and it won't change the international legal provisions or principles applicable.”

;

;Her comments were echoed by Alexander Horne, a former parliamentary lawyer, who said: that changing “our domestic law is not going to cure your breach of international laws and the supreme court was very clear that you have the refugee convention, the European convention on human rights, the United Nations convention against torture – there's a whole gamut of these things”.

;

;Even if changes in domestic law meant the supreme court felt bound to rule in favour of the government, the European court of human rights would be unlikely to do so, lawyers said.

;

;If the UK were to ignore the Strasbourg court – as the Tories' deputy chair, Lee Anderson, has suggested it should do with the supreme court – and breach international law “that would leave us with a pretty unhappy conflict with that court”, said Horne.

;More prosaically, there are doubts about whether the government would have the time to get contentious legislation through parliament and the courts before the next election.

;

;Lawyers have also raised concerns about the constitutional ramifications of the government's response. Parliamentary sovereignty means the government is entitled to legislate in response to a legal defeat, but the Bar Council said that to reverse a court's finding of fact “would raise profound and important questions about the respective role of the courts and parliament in countries that subscribe to the rule of law”.

;Republican leaders, beholden to a narrow House majority, had said they would wait for the House ethics report before deciding what to do.

;

;A Russian court has sentenced a St Petersburg artist to seven years in prison in a closely watched trial that has highlighted the severe punishments meted out to ordinary Russians for even small acts of civil protest against the invasion of Ukraine.

;

;Aleksandra “Sasha” Skochilenko, an artist, musician and activist, was found guilty on Thursday of “knowingly spreading false information about the Russian army” in March 2022. The artist admitted replacing five price tags in a local supermarket with pieces of paper urging shoppers to stop the war and resist propaganda on television.

;

;“Putin has been lying to us from television screens for 20 years: the result of these lies is our readiness to justify the war and the senseless deaths,” read one of the altered price tags, which prosecutors declared dangerous to Russian society and the state.

;

;“The Russian army bombed an art school in Mariupol. Around 400 people were hiding inside,” read another.

;

;Skochilenko is one of hundreds of Russians to face criminal charges for their opposition to the war. Many have been charged ;under the law; against spreading “fake” information about the military, which was hastily adopted after Vladimir Putin's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. The law carries a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison. ;Others charged; have included opposition politicians, activists and ;journalists;.

;

;The laws have had a chilling effect on protest in Russia, where public displays of opposition to the war have virtually disappeared.

;

;“How fragile must the prosecutor's belief in our state and society be, if he thinks that our statehood and public safety can be brought down by five small pieces of paper?” said Skochilenko, 33, in a final statement in court on Thursday.

;

;“Despite being behind bars, I am freer than you,” she said. “I'm not afraid to be different from others. Perhaps that's why my state is so afraid of me and others like me and keeps me caged like a dangerous animal.”

;
;

;;Related: ;;'It is not possible to stay quiet': Putin's first victim of 'fake news' law speaks out;

;
;

;Dozens of supporters shouted “Shame!” as a judge read out the sentence in the case. Skochilenko made the sign of a heart with her hands from the inside of a cage reserved for court defendants in Russia. Prosecutors had asked for eight years in prison.

;

;Skochilenko, who has been declared a political prisoner by the Russian human rights group Memorial, has struggled with health problems during a 19-month pre-trial detention period. She suffers from coeliac disease, which requires a gluten-free diet; bipolar disorder and a heart condition. It appeared that prosecutors were refusing her essential medicines to put additional pressure on her.

;

;Skochilenko was arrested after a 76-year-old shopper alerted police, an act compared to the Soviet-era practice of ordinary citizens spying for the security services.

;

;In an interview with the Russian website Bumaga, the woman defended her decision to complain, but conceded that the eight-year prison sentence may be too harsh.

;

;“I am the 'informer',” she said in the interview. “I'm proud of what I've done. Is it not a disgrace to see a crime and then just walk by? Did I send her to lay out these price tags? What do you want me to say, that she's a good girl? Should she be forgiven?”
